subject: physics
title: Charging by Friction and Induction MCQ Problems

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What happens to an object that loses electrons when rubbed with another material?
problems.hint: Loss of electrons means fewer negative charges.
problems.detailed: When an object loses electrons by friction, it becomes positively charged because it has a deficit of negative charges.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which material pairing is most likely involved in charging by friction?
problems.hint: Friction works best when charges stay localized.
problems.detailed: Charging by friction typically involves two insulating materials, where electrons transferred remain localized on the surfaces.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: During charging by induction, what must happen for an object to become permanently charged?
options: It must be grounded while near a charged object
problems.hint: It uses a path for charge movement without contact.
problems.detailed: In induction, the conductor must be grounded while a charged object is nearby (without touching), allowing charges to flow and leave the conductor permanently charged.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: In charging by induction, which type of material is required to allow charge redistribution?
problems.detailed: Induction requires conductors, because they have free electrons that can move and redistribute in response to an external charged object.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: If a negatively charged object is brought near a neutral conducting sphere and it is then grounded, what charge does the sphere end up with?
problems.hint: Induced charge is opposite in sign to the nearby charge.
problems.detailed: The sphere ends up positively charged because electrons flow out to ground, leaving the conductor with net positive charge once the external charge is removed.
